title: The April 2025 EVE Online Monthly Economic Report
description: Once again the economic data from New Eden has arrived so we can take a look at what happened in April. As always, others write and comment about the MER, so if you are interested there are sources worth seeking. CCP – April 2025 Monthly Economic Report CCP – April 2025 MER Forum Thread Reddit […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: Once again the economic data from New Eden has arrived so we can take a look at what happened in April. As always, others write and comment about the MER, so if you are interested there are sources…
text: Once again the economic data from New Eden has arrived so we can take a look at what happened in April. EVE Online nerds harder As always, others write and comment about the MER, so if you are interested there are sources worth seeking. CCP – April 2025 Monthly Economic Report CCP – April 2025 MER Forum Thread Reddit – April 2025 MER Thread TNG – April 2025 Activity In EVE Online TNG – A Look At The April 2025 Active ISK Delta CCP Highlights CCP’s take away from the April MER: The daily average mining value saw a slight decline of 2.5%, following higher activity levels in March. Null Sec mining activity appears to have stabilized at 56% of total mining value, potentially establishing a new baseline share—up from around 50% observed over the past few months. Increased player activity during Capsuleer Day contributed to a positive active ISK delta. The rise in Sleeper Components faucets is linked to the Capsuleer Day-themed item Sleeper Protocol Subverter. A notable spike in ISK velocity was observed, primarily driven by transactions related to skill training items. The Mineral Price Index (MPI) has decreased by 6.9% since March. Module prices dropped by 1.6%, while ship prices declined by 2.7% compared to March. A new ore type, Tyranite, has been introduced and is now included in mining reports. I want to look at some of that, but will break it out into sections below. Mining With the March mining changes, which included tier 3 system mining upgrades for null sec, many were likely waiting on the resource gathering numbers and the mineral price index update.  And, as noted above, mining went up a bit while the MPI went down a bit again in April. April 2025 – Economic Indices That said, it does still remain in all time high territory and landed still above the initial 2021 price shock when CCP decided to both starve the mineral market and make hulls battleship and above more expensive to produce.  Prices went down by the end of 2021, but mostly because people stopped logging in.  Again, covered by my post about the year of disappointment. CCP has seemingly solved some aspect of the problem of getting people to log in… average number of players logged in remains well up when compared to 2021 and 2022 levels.  But with more players came more demand and the mineral bottlenecks became more acute.  So while the downward trend is a good sign, and I can understand why CCP wouldn’t want to do anything drastic… drastic was their 2021 plan and it messed everything up… we’re still going to have to wait and see where this settles down. Likewise, the ship and module price index are starting to head down, trailing as they might well be expected to, the start of the mineral price decrease. April 2025 – Ship and Module Price Index Things seem to be headed in the right direction, though for ships and modules there are often more to it than just the mineral prices. Then there is where the mining is happening, where CCP notes that null sec has settled into 56% of the total mining output, up from 50%. April 2025 – Mining Proportion by Security Band This can probably be laid at the feet of the new T3 mining sovereignty upgrades and an enthusiasm to cash in on the high prices being driven by the scarcity of a few minerals.  So it is probably no surprise that the top ten regions for mining value are in sov null sec. Rank Region Mining Value Note 1 Vale of the Silent 3.54 trillion Fraternity 2 Impass 3.02 trillion Imperium 3 Immensea 2.99 trillion Imperium 4 Fountain 2.87 trillion The Initiative 5 Perrigen Falls 2.78 trillion PanFam 6 Tenerifis 1.83 trillion Imperium 7 The Kalevala Expanse 1.71 trillion PanFam 8 Etherium Reach 1.42 trillion PanFam 9 Domain 1.40 trillion High Sec 10 Malpais 1.29 trillion PanFam Since the measure is mining value null sec gets a leg up with more valuable ore just to start with, but high sec mining is so ubiquitous that I thought it might rank a bit higher.  Interesting that Domain, in Amarr space made the top ten.  Amarr is the second most active trade hub in New Eden, though even second place doesn’t even do 10% of Jita/Perimeter.  But, it also doesn’t get the ganker tourist traffic that the area around Jita does.  Long ago, in my high sec mining days, I moved from Jita to Amarr as my base and found I was pretty much left alone to my tasks. Meanwhile, we also got a new chart this month that shows the moon mining and compares the output between the manual harvesting method that has been in place since moon drills and moon fracking took over the old passive moon mining method, and the new Metenox automated moon mining drills that came in with the Equinox expansion last year. April 2025 – Moon mining ratios (Also, Metenox is misspelled on that chart, though I had to look up how to spell it to tell.) As you can see, with the most valuable moons, the R64s, over which wars have been fought, there seems to be a preference for the manual harvest method, which has a higher yield.  However, for the lesser moons the Metenox moon drills have become a significant aspect of moon mining, with R8 and R16 moons being mostly harvested as such. We do have to remember that, while moon mining output is vital for a lot of production, especially tech II production, its overall value in the economy is still pretty small when compared to asteroid mining.  Here are the top ten regions for moon mining. Rank Region Mining Value Note 1 Vale of the Silent 5.60 billion Fraternity 2 Domain 3.43 billion High Sec 3 Immensea 2.81 billion Imperium 4 Fountain 2.53 billion The Initiative 5 Kador 2.20 billion High Sec 6 The Forge 2.13 billion High Sec 7 Impass 2.07 billion Imperium 8 Etherium Reach 1.92 billion PanFam 9 Khanid 1.83 billion High Sec 10 Perrigen Falls 1.65 billion PanFam Monthly value is measured in billions rather than trillions… and not even double digit billions.  My income in April from planetary would put me in about 15th place by comparison.  And there is the fact that high sec figured in four of the top ten spots because 0.5 security systems can set up moon mining operations and those yield some standard ore if I recall right. Of course, I am not sure how seriously to take those valuations.  CCP has been off on other pricing and, while the moon goo market has been plagued by over production, I couldn’t tell you if the pricing has been suppressed by that much… or if null sec powers would bother setting up as many moon mining operations as they have if they were only going to yield value of less than a dreadnought or two. Seems sus. ISK Active Delta and the Velocity of ISK Then I have a couple of quick thoughts about the mention of ISK in CCP’s highlights. The Active ISK Delta is part of their monthly measure of the economy, where the total amount of ISK is the previous month’s total plus the ISK faucets for the month, minus the ISK sinks for the month, then modified by the Active ISK Delta, which is the amount of ISK CCP has taken out of the economy due to RMT investigations as well as the coming and goings of players from the game.  When you haven’t played for 90 days CCP doesn’t count your ISK as part of the economy and it becomes a debit to the Active ISK Delta. Likewise, when people come back to the game, their ISK holdings are a credit to that account.  And, as noted above, you hand out five days of free Omega time lapsed players are incentivized to log in, thus marking them as active and part of the economy.  I know I logged in my three alt accounts to collect those five days and get in a bit of training. So there we go, the Active ISK Delta, which is usually a negative value, actually went positive for April.  And you can bet it will likely be so again for May with the launch of a new expansion, an event that almost always includes five days of Omega. April 2025 – Balance of ISK Then there is the mention of the velocity of ISK, which popped up quite a bit in April. April 2025 – Velocity of ISK Once again, this indicates that velocity is, and remains, flat for standard market transactions (purple line on the chart), but once you include contracts things (blue line) pick up and if you then include PLEX and PLEX accessories (orange line) the velocity is clearly spiking. This is because PLEX has become the economy in New Eden so when CCP does something to drive PLEX related purchases, as they did again in April, the price of PLEX goes up, passing well into the 6 million ISK per this time around, which impacts everything around it. As noted in that post I linked, CCP is still fumbling around to figure out how to deal with this sort of thing as they have an incentive to drive PLEX usage in the in-game New Eden store as that is the point where they are allowed to claim the revenue for the PLEX purchase, but that has driven them to introduce more and more things valued in PLEX… SKINR is one of the more recent items… without being able to incentivize people to spend real world cash on PLEX to keep the PLEX price from climbing or at least gyrating wildly when they need to juice their revenue by giving an incentive to spend PLEX. Cash shops and RMT currencies are a thing in a lot of games, including World or Warcraft with the WoW token.  But I not sure anybody has integrated their RMT currency into their in-game economy as deeply as CCP.  Always on the bleeding edge! Just to go back to something I said above, back in 2009 we had a discussion about PLEX and whether using it was opting out of the economy.  Since then, PLEX has become the economy.  So here in 2025, if you don’t use PLEX in some way are you opting out of the economy? 2025 Destruction Summary April saw a decline in destruction relative to March.  Sure, there was one less day in the month, but the average losses per day were down as well.  Jester’s charts showed fairly comparable population track across the two months, though that was skewed a bit by the 5 days of free Omega subscription time that CCP handed out mid-month. April 2024 – Average players online daily This makes the four year comparo chart, which I tend to favor for a year over year view, a bit deceptive as it lacks the 7 day rolling average, which is where one can see the effect of the free time.  That pulls the overall much up a bit on the 30 day average, but the line is likely propped up by New Eden day trippers looking to cash in that dedicated combat pilots looking for a fight. Or such is my theory.  It at least matches the chart above with the numbers below. Loss Count Total January – 514,511 total losses February – 427,027 total losses March – 538,625 total losses April – 464,177 total losses Avg Losses per Day January – 16,597.13 losses per day February – 15,250.96 losses per day March – 17,375.00 losses per day April – 15,472.57 losses per day Total ISK Value Lost January – 46.86 trillion ISK February – 44.55 trillion ISK March – 50.78 trillion ISK April – 47.77 trillion ISK Total ISK Value Lost per Day January – 1,511.77 billion ISK per day February – 1,590.99 billion ISK per day March – 1,638.07 billion ISK per day April – 1592.22 billion ISK per day February remains the low point of the year, even on an average per day basis, but April wasn’t all that far behind. The End of Uitra Watch? As expected, with the patch that closed the AIR Career Program skill point exploit, destruction of shuttles in Uitra, once more than a third of all shuttles in New Eden, has fallen off.  Here are the numbers for the system so far in 2025: January Total – 42,984 Shuttles – 28,675 Corvettes – 13,828 February Total – 36,495 Shuttles – 18,364 Corvettes – 17,658 March Total – 32,392 Shuttles – 18,187 Corvettes – 13,774 April Total – 1,252 Shuttles – 701 Corvettes – 368 I am a bit surprise that there were even 701 shuttle losses in April, but I suspect that some people are still out there doing the program one last time on a main or a skill point extraction alt that they had previously ignored. That was still enough to put Uitra in fourth place overall, but that was with a number which was a shadow of its former dominance of this ranking. Rank Hull Count System Region 1 Shuttle 1228 Ahbazon Genesis 2 Shuttle 1077 Stacmon Placid 3 Shuttle 994 Jita The Forge 4 Shuttle 701 Uitra The Forge 5 Shuttle 573 Azdaja Redoubt K-R00033 6 Shuttle 414 Tama The Citadel 7 Shuttle 410 Sanctified Vidette K-R00033 8 Shuttle 381 Liberated Barbican K-R00033 9 Shuttle 379 Sentinel MZ K-R00033 10 Shuttle 373 Amarr Domain Shuttle losses overall for New Eden in April were 18,981, way down from the 58,063 blow up in March, 56% of which were lost in Uitra. Shuttle losses now are mostly just normal losses.  They happen in low sec or in high population systems like Jita where people still do dumb things like transport PLEX with them, or apparently in event systems.  At least that is what I think the three systems in K-R00033 are. Anyway, that wraps things up for April.  May will see the impact of Fanfest, such that it is, and a new expansion at the end of the month.
html:
Once again the economic data from New Eden has arrived so we can take a look at what happened in April.

EVE Online nerds harder

As always, others write and comment about the MER, so if you are interested there are sources worth seeking.

  • CCP – April 2025 Monthly Economic Report
  • CCP – April 2025 MER Forum Thread
  • Reddit – April 2025 MER Thread
  • TNG – April 2025 Activity In EVE Online
  • TNG – A Look At The April 2025 Active ISK Delta

CCP Highlights

CCP’s take away from the April MER:

  • The daily average mining value saw a slight decline of 2.5%, following higher activity levels in March.
  • Null Sec mining activity appears to have stabilized at 56% of total mining value, potentially establishing a new baseline share—up from around 50% observed over the past few months.
  • Increased player activity during Capsuleer Day contributed to a positive active ISK delta.
  • The rise in Sleeper Components faucets is linked to the Capsuleer Day-themed item Sleeper Protocol Subverter.
  • A notable spike in ISK velocity was observed, primarily driven by transactions related to skill training items.
  • The Mineral Price Index (MPI) has decreased by 6.9% since March.
  • Module prices dropped by 1.6%, while ship prices declined by 2.7% compared to March.
  • A new ore type, Tyranite, has been introduced and is now included in mining reports.

I want to look at some of that, but will break it out into sections below.

Mining

With the March mining changes, which included tier 3 system mining upgrades for null sec, many were likely waiting on the resource gathering numbers and the mineral price index update.  And, as noted above, mining went up a bit while the MPI went down a bit again in April.

April 2025 – Economic Indices

That said, it does still remain in all time high territory and landed still above the initial 2021 price shock when CCP decided to both starve the mineral market and make hulls battleship and above more expensive to produce.  Prices went down by the end of 2021, but mostly because people stopped logging in.  Again, covered by my post about the year of disappointment.

CCP has seemingly solved some aspect of the problem of getting people to log in… average number of players logged in remains well up when compared to 2021 and 2022 levels.  But with more players came more demand and the mineral bottlenecks became more acute.  So while the downward trend is a good sign, and I can understand why CCP wouldn’t want to do anything drastic… drastic was their 2021 plan and it messed everything up… we’re still going to have to wait and see where this settles down.

Likewise, the ship and module price index are starting to head down, trailing as they might well be expected to, the start of the mineral price decrease.

April 2025 – Ship and Module Price Index

Things seem to be headed in the right direction, though for ships and modules there are often more to it than just the mineral prices.

Then there is where the mining is happening, where CCP notes that null sec has settled into 56% of the total mining output, up from 50%.

April 2025 – Mining Proportion by Security Band

This can probably be laid at the feet of the new T3 mining sovereignty upgrades and an enthusiasm to cash in on the high prices being driven by the scarcity of a few minerals.  So it is probably no surprise that the top ten regions for mining value are in sov null sec.

Rank Region Mining Value Note
1 Vale of the Silent 3.54 trillion Fraternity
2 Impass 3.02 trillion Imperium
3 Immensea 2.99 trillion Imperium
4 Fountain 2.87 trillion The Initiative
5 Perrigen Falls 2.78 trillion PanFam
6 Tenerifis 1.83 trillion Imperium
7 The Kalevala Expanse 1.71 trillion PanFam
8 Etherium Reach 1.42 trillion PanFam
9 Domain 1.40 trillion High Sec
10 Malpais 1.29 trillion PanFam

Since the measure is mining value null sec gets a leg up with more valuable ore just to start with, but high sec mining is so ubiquitous that I thought it might rank a bit higher.  Interesting that Domain, in Amarr space made the top ten.  Amarr is the second most active trade hub in New Eden, though even second place doesn’t even do 10% of Jita/Perimeter.  But, it also doesn’t get the ganker tourist traffic that the area around Jita does.  Long ago, in my high sec mining days, I moved from Jita to Amarr as my base and found I was pretty much left alone to my tasks.

Meanwhile, we also got a new chart this month that shows the moon mining and compares the output between the manual harvesting method that has been in place since moon drills and moon fracking took over the old passive moon mining method, and the new Metenox automated moon mining drills that came in with the Equinox expansion last year.

April 2025 – Moon mining ratios

(Also, Metenox is misspelled on that chart, though I had to look up how to spell it to tell.)

As you can see, with the most valuable moons, the R64s, over which wars have been fought, there seems to be a preference for the manual harvest method, which has a higher yield.  However, for the lesser moons the Metenox moon drills have become a significant aspect of moon mining, with R8 and R16 moons being mostly harvested as such.

We do have to remember that, while moon mining output is vital for a lot of production, especially tech II production, its overall value in the economy is still pretty small when compared to asteroid mining.  Here are the top ten regions for moon mining.

Rank Region Mining Value Note
1 Vale of the Silent 5.60 billion Fraternity
2 Domain 3.43 billion High Sec
3 Immensea 2.81 billion Imperium
4 Fountain 2.53 billion The Initiative
5 Kador 2.20 billion High Sec
6 The Forge 2.13 billion High Sec
7 Impass 2.07 billion Imperium
8 Etherium Reach 1.92 billion PanFam
9 Khanid 1.83 billion High Sec
10 Perrigen Falls 1.65 billion PanFam

Monthly value is measured in billions rather than trillions… and not even double digit billions.  My income in April from planetary would put me in about 15th place by comparison.  And there is the fact that high sec figured in four of the top ten spots because 0.5 security systems can set up moon mining operations and those yield some standard ore if I recall right.

Of course, I am not sure how seriously to take those valuations.  CCP has been off on other pricing and, while the moon goo market has been plagued by over production, I couldn’t tell you if the pricing has been suppressed by that much… or if null sec powers would bother setting up as many moon mining operations as they have if they were only going to yield value of less than a dreadnought or two.

Seems sus.

ISK Active Delta and the Velocity of ISK

Then I have a couple of quick thoughts about the mention of ISK in CCP’s highlights.

The Active ISK Delta is part of their monthly measure of the economy, where the total amount of ISK is the previous month’s total plus the ISK faucets for the month, minus the ISK sinks for the month, then modified by the Active ISK Delta, which is the amount of ISK CCP has taken out of the economy due to RMT investigations as well as the coming and goings of players from the game.  When you haven’t played for 90 days CCP doesn’t count your ISK as part of the economy and it becomes a debit to the Active ISK Delta.

Likewise, when people come back to the game, their ISK holdings are a credit to that account.  And, as noted above, you hand out five days of free Omega time lapsed players are incentivized to log in, thus marking them as active and part of the economy.  I know I logged in my three alt accounts to collect those five days and get in a bit of training.

So there we go, the Active ISK Delta, which is usually a negative value, actually went positive for April.  And you can bet it will likely be so again for May with the launch of a new expansion, an event that almost always includes five days of Omega.

April 2025 – Balance of ISK

Then there is the mention of the velocity of ISK, which popped up quite a bit in April.

April 2025 – Velocity of ISK

Once again, this indicates that velocity is, and remains, flat for standard market transactions (purple line on the chart), but once you include contracts things (blue line) pick up and if you then include PLEX and PLEX accessories (orange line) the velocity is clearly spiking.

This is because PLEX has become the economy in New Eden so when CCP does something to drive PLEX related purchases, as they did again in April, the price of PLEX goes up, passing well into the 6 million ISK per this time around, which impacts everything around it.

As noted in that post I linked, CCP is still fumbling around to figure out how to deal with this sort of thing as they have an incentive to drive PLEX usage in the in-game New Eden store as that is the point where they are allowed to claim the revenue for the PLEX purchase, but that has driven them to introduce more and more things valued in PLEX… SKINR is one of the more recent items… without being able to incentivize people to spend real world cash on PLEX to keep the PLEX price from climbing or at least gyrating wildly when they need to juice their revenue by giving an incentive to spend PLEX.

Cash shops and RMT currencies are a thing in a lot of games, including World or Warcraft with the WoW token.  But I not sure anybody has integrated their RMT currency into their in-game economy as deeply as CCP.  Always on the bleeding edge!

Just to go back to something I said above, back in 2009 we had a discussion about PLEX and whether using it was opting out of the economy.  Since then, PLEX has become the economy.  So here in 2025, if you don’t use PLEX in some way are you opting out of the economy?

2025 Destruction Summary

April saw a decline in destruction relative to March.  Sure, there was one less day in the month, but the average losses per day were down as well.  Jester’s charts showed fairly comparable population track across the two months, though that was skewed a bit by the 5 days of free Omega subscription time that CCP handed out mid-month.

April 2024 – Average players online daily

This makes the four year comparo chart, which I tend to favor for a year over year view, a bit deceptive as it lacks the 7 day rolling average, which is where one can see the effect of the free time.  That pulls the overall much up a bit on the 30 day average, but the line is likely propped up by New Eden day trippers looking to cash in that dedicated combat pilots looking for a fight.

Or such is my theory.  It at least matches the chart above with the numbers below.

  • Loss Count Total
    • January – 514,511 total losses
    • February – 427,027 total losses
    • March – 538,625 total losses
    • April – 464,177 total losses
  • Avg Losses per Day
    • January – 16,597.13 losses per day
    • February – 15,250.96 losses per day
    • March – 17,375.00 losses per day
    • April – 15,472.57 losses per day
  • Total ISK Value Lost
    • January – 46.86 trillion ISK
    • February – 44.55 trillion ISK
    • March – 50.78 trillion ISK
    • April – 47.77 trillion ISK
  • Total ISK Value Lost per Day
    • January – 1,511.77 billion ISK per day
    • February – 1,590.99 billion ISK per day
    • March – 1,638.07 billion ISK per day
    • April – 1592.22 billion ISK per day

February remains the low point of the year, even on an average per day basis, but April wasn’t all that far behind.

The End of Uitra Watch?

As expected, with the patch that closed the AIR Career Program skill point exploit, destruction of shuttles in Uitra, once more than a third of all shuttles in New Eden, has fallen off.  Here are the numbers for the system so far in 2025:

  • January
    • Total – 42,984
    • Shuttles – 28,675
    • Corvettes – 13,828
  • February
    • Total – 36,495
    • Shuttles – 18,364
    • Corvettes – 17,658
  • March
    • Total – 32,392
    • Shuttles – 18,187
    • Corvettes – 13,774
  • April
    • Total – 1,252
    • Shuttles – 701
    • Corvettes – 368

I am a bit surprise that there were even 701 shuttle losses in April, but I suspect that some people are still out there doing the program one last time on a main or a skill point extraction alt that they had previously ignored.

That was still enough to put Uitra in fourth place overall, but that was with a number which was a shadow of its former dominance of this ranking.

Rank Hull Count System Region
1 Shuttle 1228 Ahbazon Genesis
2 Shuttle 1077 Stacmon Placid
3 Shuttle 994 Jita The Forge
4 Shuttle 701 Uitra The Forge
5 Shuttle 573 Azdaja Redoubt K-R00033
6 Shuttle 414 Tama The Citadel
7 Shuttle 410 Sanctified Vidette K-R00033
8 Shuttle 381 Liberated Barbican K-R00033
9 Shuttle 379 Sentinel MZ K-R00033
10 Shuttle 373 Amarr Domain

Shuttle losses overall for New Eden in April were 18,981, way down from the 58,063 blow up in March, 56% of which were lost in Uitra.

Shuttle losses now are mostly just normal losses.  They happen in low sec or in high population systems like Jita where people still do dumb things like transport PLEX with them, or apparently in event systems.  At least that is what I think the three systems in K-R00033 are.

Anyway, that wraps things up for April.  May will see the impact of Fanfest, such that it is, and a new expansion at the end of the month.
